THURSDAY, JULY 13, 1905.

div.head: LORD OROMER AND LORD
div.p: KITCHENER. The extreme importance of the reoent letter from the speoial correspondent of the "Times” in Icdia on Lord Kitchener’s handling ot the Egyptian Army leads tbe "Speotator” to in dolge in some reflection-, which are of speoial interest to Egyptian readers. Though the aub- j ot is necessarily one of great diffionlty and deli- cioy, rays our contemporary, the correspondent of the ‘Times’ does not shrink from handling the question of personality in Lord Kitchener’s case. He declares that Lord Kitchener’s friends oan hardly deny that his mastertulneaa grows with inoreasing power, and that the orders which be so often hastily issnes and as hastily withdraws no longer show the same industry

and applicition to detail, or the same devotion to eoonomy, which characterised his work in’ Egypt:— 'Still less c»n his friends deny that he has no personal knowledge of the Indian character; for he has never had any Indian experience, and arriving for the first time in India as C >tn- mander-in-Chief, he has not had the opport- unities of coming into contact with Indian life which most of his predecessors had found in the earlier stages of their career. His constitu- tional intolerance of all opposition unfits him to learn from those who have had the ex- perience whioh he lacks. In faot, with regard both to the Indian Army and to the question of army administration, Lord Kitchener’s views, which are generally assumed to have been based on his experience since he came to India, were brought with him ready-made from England, and, within a few weeks after he had landed at Bombay, he expressed them daring the Delhi Darbar as forcibly as at any time einoe. Facts have been made to fit in with them.” The correspondent oi the "Times” ends his letter by tooohing opon a matter to which we should not ourselves have thought it prudent to allude. Sinoe, however, he has taken the res- ponsibility of dealing with it and has made it pnblio, we feel that reticence in onr case is no longer neoeasary. After speaking of Lord Kit- chener’s administration of the Egyptian Army, and pointing out—whioh is no more than the bare truth—how largely the restraining and direoting influence of Lord Cromer’s experi- ence and wisdom contributed to the sacoess achieved, he proceeds to mention how "the recocqaest of the Sadan was very nearly wrecked not long afterwards in a disaster doe to the same defeota of whioh many people dread tbe conséquences in India” :— "Only a short time before Lord Kitchener was ordered to Booth Africa, an incipient mutiny amongst the native troops in the Sudan, whioh arose ont of his disregard in peace-time for peculiar idiosyncrasies that be had safely ignored so locg as the excitement of active service lasted, was only detected and soppressed at the eleventh hoar. The sup- pression of Lord Cromer’s “opinion’ on Lord Kitohener’s scheme is easily explained when one remembers that he alone oombined with an intimate knowledge of the Indian aspects of the question a still more intimate knowledge of the defeots of Lord Kitohener’s qualities.” Since the matter has been raised in public, the "Speotator” feels jastified in endorsing what is stated by the correspondent of the "Times.” The mutiny of the Sadanese troops at Khartoum—for ma tiny, in effect, it was—was, it oan hardly be doubted, due to the defects in the military administration of Lord Kitchener, defeots wbioh in peace time, while Lord Kit- ohener was under the direot iuflaence of Lord Cromer in Cairo, were prevented from assuming dangerous proportions, bat which were exagge- rated by the virtual autonomy whioh Lord Kitohenerneoessarily enjoyed in theSadan. Tbe correspondent of the "Times” is, however, it thinks, wrong in saying that the outbreak took plaoe before Lord Kitchener oeased to be Sirdar: "Unless we are mistaken, it took place shortly after his departure. This fact makes no difference as far as the moral to be drawn is oonoefoed. Though the aotnal outbreak did not oooor till a few weeks after Lord Kitohener had left Egypt for Sooth Africa, the conditions whioh produced the outbreak were, as we have said, the result of Lord Kitohener’s policy. In the same way, it is more than likely, if any sarioos trouble arises owing to Lord Kitchener’s handling of tile Indian Army, that snob trouble will not arise till Lord Kitchener’s period of offioe has expired, as it will expire in another eighteen mcQuths. It is when his influence—which, if injudioioas, is no doubt also potent -has been withdrawn that we may expect to reap the fall fruits of the polity which has placed that delioate machine, the native Army of India, at the absolute disposal of a man who knows little of its tradi- tions or peoaliar character, and whose belief is that as long as soldiers oan be forced to obey all must bs well with an army,”

div.head: ALDERSHOT RAGGING CASE.
div.p: 'KN'TKN'CKS ON OFFICERS.

( Gazette's Special Service ) London, Monday. The sentences in the Aldershot ragging oase have been given. Colonel Cnthbert is placed on half pay, Captain Straoey removed from the adjutancy and severely censored, and the others have b:en severely oensored and their leave stopped for periods ranging from six to tw live months, and they are also superseded for promotion.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL.
div.p: Mena House. Mena House Hotel will close for the season ou the 1st of May. Egyptian Estates Co. The shares of this company are now all quoted on the Bourse ex-oonpon. New Post Office. A post offioe-for the exchange of correspon dance, parcel and money order servioe hés been opened at Bab el Khalk (Cairo). Public Health Department. M. Denis E. Zoulas, physician, and Messrs. Zia Mohamed, Monssa Yaoonb, and Christo Oconomopoulo, pharmacists, have been antho- rised to practise in Egypt. Englishwoman’s Mysterious Death. The oourt of enquiry into the ciroumstanoes attending the death of Miss Jessie Brown did not terminate yesterday and was, adjourn- ed until Thursday next for farther evidence. Imperial Ottoman Bank. Our Constantinople Correspondent states that the Imperial Ottoman Bank has opened a branch at Tripoli in Africa, and appointed to it M. Christodonlidès, sub-director of the bank at Aleppo. Garrison Church. During the absecoe of Rev. F. B. N. Norman Lee, C.F., who left Alexandria on Friday, the clergy of St Mark’s and All Saints’ are res ponsible for Sunday and week-day duty at the garrison chnrch. Ariston Aerated Water Co. This oompany have taken np the sole agency of Simpson’s well known Honse of Lords’ whisky, whioh is reoommended by all the medical papers as a healthy and invigora ting drink. New Egyptian Companies. Four new companies were authorised by the Council of Ministers yesterday. These are the Artificial Stone Company, the Grandes Garages d’Bgypte, the Cairo 8obnrban Build ing Land, and the Exoelsior Hotels Company. Concert. We may remind oor readers of the oonoert to be given to morrow evening in the saloons of Shepheard’s Hotel, in aid of the Soldiers and Sailors’ Families Association. The ooncert is under the distinguished patronage of the Rt. Hon. the Earl of Cromer. Mpj ir-General Sir P. R WiDgate Paoha, Brigadier-Gen. G. M Bullock, and Idris Ragheb Paoha.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: According to papers to hand this morning. Prince Djemil Tonssoom has left Paris for Monte Carlo in his antomobil».
Lord Cromer paid an offioial visit on Saturday :D H. E. Mahmoud Paoha Sidby, the 3overnor cf Cairo.
Briv. General G.M. Bollock, C.B., command ing the Army of Occupation, and Major A. R Hoskins, D.S.O., General Staff, came down to Alexandria from Cairo on Sunday.
1 iie marriage of the Hon. Henry G. Godol pbin pelbam, Sudan Civil Service, with Miss Agnes Ollerhead, was solemnised at St. Michael’s Chnrch, Minehead, last Thursday.

Among the passengers who left for Europe on Saturday by the Austrian Lloyd steamer were Count Hohenstein, Capt. Mahon, Rev and Mrs. Potter, Count and Countess Piccolo mini. Prof. Schuok, Talama Bey, Mr. and Mrs de Forster, etc.

div.head: BRIGAND'S DEPREDATIONS
div.p: 101 PEOPLE KILLED

A brigand named Hailo Miriam el Habashi has made a descent on Aboa Golnd, some 60 miles N E. of Gedaref. It appears that 101 people were killed (among them 13 women) and 16 wounded. 41 men and 133 women oarried off captive with oattle and horees. Military posts have been established on the frontier to prevent the reonrrenoe of snoh outrages and Abyssinian and Sudanese Govern monts are taking concerted measnres to hnnt Hailo Miriam and his band. We hear that the district in whioh Hailo Miriam is operating is almost entirely uninha- bited exoept by robbers and elephant hunters, who in the past have issned f om their fastnesses and attacked the Takoori villager1, near Gedaref. It is hoped that this band will soon be brought to book by the conbimed efforts of the Sudan and Abyssinian Governments. The raid has of course no political bearing whatever.

div.head: SUDAN CONGO AGREEMENT.
div.p: An agreement between Great Britain and the Congo Free State regarding the Lado Enolave has been negotiated at Bruesels between the British Minister and Baron van Betvelde, Minister of State of the Congo.

div.head: THE PLAGUE
div.p: Sunday’s bulletin reported 8 cases, 5 of them deaths in hospital at Deshna, and 3—all eading in deafh — at the Samalout hospital. Oj Monday the bulletin was graver. It reported 11 oases. 3 of them dying in hospital and eight outside hospital at Deshna (of these seven—all pnenmonio—took place among per- sons under observation) ; 10 oases with 3 deaths in hospital in the Samalont district, of whioh 5 wire pneumonic ; one death out of hospital at Tautah ; one death at Nag Ha madi (pnenmonio), the viitirn coming from Dashna ; one oase at Eokhana (Beni SoneL) During the week ending on Sunday 57 oases of plague were reported throughout the whole of Egypt. Of these 19 took plaoe at Samalout, 5 at Maukatein, in the Samalont district, apd 40 at Dethoa. The majority of the oases whioh occurred at Deshna last week were reported attacking individuals who bad been in oontact with other viotims of the disease and had in coneequence been placed under observation. The sitnation shows a deoided improvement at the village ofOwlatAmou, Keneh district and province, where numerous cases of plague had been reported since the first outbreak. The only case remaining under treatment has been cured.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN PRINCE
div.p: No news has yet been received at the Alexandria offices of the Prinoe Line in regard to the acoident to the Egyptian P.ince announ oed in to days telegrams. Among the passengers oft board were Mrs. Knott, the wife of the managing director of the Prince Line, and a party of friends.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: H. H. the Khedive gave audience at Abdeen yesterday to Lord Cromer, Crookshank Pasha, Gillson Bey, M. Alician, and M. Rafael Soares, who thanked his Highness for having sent his representative to the fanerai of the late M. Felix Soares.

div.head: FASHIONABLE MARRIAGE
div.p: The wedding of Miss Virginia Spiro, only daughter of S. Spiro Bey and Mrs. Spiro, to Mr. Zaki Ibrahim Mikhail, took place at 5. p.m. on Sunday at Moharrem Bey. An immense marquee had been erected close to the house of the bridegroom’s father, and when it was lighted up with the massive chandeliers, etc., it presented a most brilliant effect. The bride looked charming in a lovely white silk dress and orange blossoms. She was snpported by her two cousins as bridesmaids. Among the very numerous guests present we noticed H.E. Mustapha Pacha lbadi, Go- vernor of Alexandria; Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield, Director General of Ports and Light- houses; Lewa Gedge Paoha, Sob-Direotor Ge- neral; Mrs. and Miss Gedge, Miss Mainwaring, Capt. and Mrs. Loveland, Mr. Murphy, Miralai Marray Bey, Miralai Ahmel Bakry Bey, Capt. Falooner Bey, Mr. and Mrs. Davies Bryan, Mr. Malaval, Mr. and Mrs. J. E. Roberts, Mr. and Mrs. A. Grafton, Mr. and Mis. J. Purvis, cap- tain and offioers of H.H.S. Aida, Mr. Jonlet, Capt. Borg Rnggier, Capt. Formolaro, Dr. and Mrs. Chorlian, Mr. and Mrs. Petrachi, Mr. and Mrs. Liebsohn, Mr. and Mrs. E. Kirby, and the

div.head: PORT SAID SALT ASSOCIATION
div.p: We learn that the Port Said Salt Associa- tion, Ltd., has signed a contraot with the Egyptian M vrkets Ltd., whereby the former oompany is entitled to make nse of the 117 markets belonging to the Market, Company for the sale of its salt throughout Egypt Of these, 72 are in Lower and 45 in Upper Egypt.

div.head: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE
div.p: A Cairo correspondent writes l'- An amusing result of the Akaba dispute is evident in the Press. The Egyptian Moslem newspapers have takèn np a polioy of defend- ing the Saltan’s olaims to the territory in dispute against tie pretensions of the Khédi- vial Government. On the other hand, it is necessary for the Anglophils paît of the Press to protest against the infringement of the Khedive’s territory by the Saltan and to de- mand the inviolability of the Egyptian soil against the trespass of Ottoman troops. Both points ot view are apparently adopted in all seriousness and a olimax is reaohed when the Progres/’whoas an Anglophile is "plus royaliste que le roi,” publishes a paragraph oalliog the “Egyptian Patriot” a traitor. Here it is :— Nons savons depuis longtemps que le Lena du pacha Monatapha Kamel est pins turo qu’égyptien. Jnsqn’ioi cependant ce journal mettait quelque soin à sauver les apparences : il se faisait bien l’avocat de la Porte, mais il le faisait aveo q^e’qoo discrétion, et il ne man- quait jamais de noyer ses idées panislamiques dans ses tirades patriotiqaes en faveur de la création d’nne ohambre de députés en Egypte et de l’évaonation de ce pays par les troupes britsnniqoep. Mais dans son nnméro d’hier, le

Leica a jeté le mafqne, et il soutient ouverte- Viotoria College, the Maltese Victoria Sohool, ment le prétendu droit do Saltan à l’occupatioifl' de territoires appartenant à l’Egypte en vertu de stipulations international. Cela s’appelle trahir son pays. Nons signalons h nos oonfrè’es indigènes cette manière d’agir dn journal turcophile. Il voient aujourd'hui oe que vaut le patriotisme de Moustapha Kamel.

div.head: BLACK DIAMOND MINSTRELS
div.p: The performance of the “Black Diamond” Minstrels, in aid of the Alexandria Swimming Club and Philoptoohos oharitv, took place on Saturday evening in the Z;z‘nia Theatre and went off wi'.h considerable sneoess. The performance was an attractive one, and with the exception of a rather long interval between the two parts, which perhaps shoold be exonsed on a “first-night” production, wasgone through without a hitch. Of the several pleasing ballads and songs presented in the first part, “Under the thadow of the Pyramid,” sung by Miss Delanoy, proved the most popular num- ber and was very heartily encored. “The Caterpillar and the Rose,” very ably sung by Miss M. C. Davies, also seoured a good deal of applanre. Mr. Peroy Smith was heard to great advantage in “As the ivy loves the oak,” and tho other songs were all very well reoeived by the audience. Mr. Pearce Hill as “Bones” was very quickly in tonoh with his audience and created roars of laughter, whilst Mr. King as “Tamho” seoured an encore for an exceedingly droll rendering of “The smile that won’t come off.” In the second part several items were well received. The quartette in “The Man- hattan Clnb” entitled “Bill of Fare,” sung by Messrs. P. Smith, Rimmer, J. Parvis, Heaton, and Griffiths, was very effective. The sextette •‘Floradora down South” was particularly well done and showed signs of many rehearsals. This was very deservedly encored. The “dusky damsels” were Messrs. J. Capponi, L. Payne, and Tulloch, whilst the “darkey dons” were Messrs. A. Purvis, Griffiths, and Rimmer- The banjo and guitar quintette also proved a popular number, as did the song “In a birch canoe,” sung by Miss Davies and assisted by the Misses Delanoy and Mrs. Sowerby, all ot whom looked charming in their pretty gowns and powdered hair. Eaoh lady was presented with a handsome boeqaet. Mr. Peeroe Hill gave an excellent ventrilo- quial performance, introducing four figures, and singing two fongs, one of which was snug by “Mrs. f^wdnst” with a ’cello obligato given by “Mr. Sawdnst,” which brought forth great applause. “Preghiera” from Puocini’s Tosca and Flegier’s romarce' Oabli,” sang by Mme Landi, were very highly appreciated. Mme Landi was

div.head: NEW HOTEL FOR ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: THE PALACE HOTEL COMPANY

New Khédivial Hotel. It is intended to rno a new first-c’ass hotel ia the fashionable quar- ter cf the city, and for this purpose the large building belonging to Mr. Amabile Combo at the oorner of Rosetta-a venae and Mariette Pacha-street has been taken on lease. It is intended to add considerably to the existing buildings at the back and to make a fine winter- garden, which will be heated by steam daring the winter, to fit* ap a large bar facing the street, motor-garages, life, billiard rooms, and all the usnal accessories of an np-to date first- olass hotel. One of the great features of the hotel will be a magnificent restaurant, which is sure to be largely patronised. At the beginning, the hotel will contain one hundred and fifty bedrooms, including a number of separate suites with private bathrooms. The chairman of the board of directors of the oompany is Bartau Paoha.

div.head: A CASINO AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: Yesterday an application was made to the Alexandria Municipality for a concession fjr the establishment of a casino on the new quay. It is proposed to form a company with a capital of from £80,005 to £100,000 and to erect a building similar to establishments at Ostend and other watering-places in Europe. A site of 7,000 pics has been asked for. After a conces- sion of fifty years the casirib is to become the property of the Municipality. Mr. J. M. Aghion and Mr. G. Ralli are the promoters of the scheme.

div.head: SAN STEFANO FLOWER SHOW
div.p: To thb Editor or the “Egyptian Gazette.” Sir,— I have just come from the above, which was extensively advertised to remain open until 7 p.m. At least a quarter of an hoar before then, however, admission was refused. Personally it woold not have muoh mattered hot for the rudeness of the objeotors, as my party had been there before. The same thing might, however, and probably did happen to persons who had only just paid for tiokets at the entrâtes to the Casino grounds. What way of obtaining money would this have been Î Yours faithfully, Correct Time.

div.head: EASTER AT MANSOURAH AND TANTAH.
div.p: The Easter festival was celebrated as bright- ly as evsr at Mansourah. Constantinia and Zifta contributed many beant:ful flowers Early service at 7.45 allowed the Chaplain to get to Tantah for a service of Matins and H. C. at II a.m. Flowers there seem to have been soaroe, indeed only enough for altar vases, but Mr. MoCarthy and Mrs. Angel had decorated the room with palm branches There was a good oougregatiou. Evensong at Man son rah, 6 30, was also well attended. Mrs. Mnrdooh, Mrs. Smith, Miss Smith and Mrs. Watkins had decorated the room with white flowers.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA MUNICIPALITY.
div.p: The report of the Administrator of the Municipality on the accoants for the past year is conveniently issned for the first time in a single publication, oombining the reports ot all the varions heads of departments. Heretofore, the latter were eaoh separately issued, but the Municipality has now followed the examp'e of the Publio Works Department in its report. There is ore serious omission, there being not a single notification anywhere throughout the report as to where it is to be obtained and what price. Although it has only just been published, we have several times been asked if it is on sale, bat nobody seems to know whether snoh is or is not the case. For the sake of encouraging public interest in the Municipality it would be advisable to allow the report to be on sale at looal booksellers. The publication consists of the following reports :—

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID
div.p: WHERE EAST MEETS WEST.

(From our Cob respondent). Port Said, Sunday. To anyone who is fond of studying the characteristics of different nationalities, Port Said offers a field of observation as interesting as any in the world. Here East meets West— here we have types of all the world and his wife. In nothing is this more noticeable than in times of festivity and holiday. At the recent Easter celebrations, whilst the Latin races vied with each other in their enthusiastic celebration of religious ritual and ceremonies, the Anglo Saxons, though not unmindful of the origin of the festival, made less parade, and supplemented it by indulgence in their national games. In the celebration of Shem el-Necsim there was the usual exodus of the native populace to the “Sweet Wateis,” where many Europeans also foregathered in the afternoon. Port Said Music. The Port Said bands discoursed mnsio whilst old and young enjoyed wandering through the plantation. It is m fortunate that the French name of one of the bands has so suggestive an English sound, giving an opportunity for the amateur humourist to make facetious remarks at the expense, not of the band, bat of their own reputation for wit. However, its mnsio in no way belies its title, and we understand that in the near future the Lyre intends still farther to enhance its reputation by the introduction of some new blood and new orchestral music. Naval “At Home ” Capt Weymouth and the officers of H.M.S. Minerva held an "At Home” on Easter Monday, whioh was largely attended and pronounced to be a great success. Among those present were the Consol-Genera], Mr. Cameron, Sohaloh Bey, Dickson Bey, Rev. Canon, Mrs. and Miss Strange, Mr. and Mrs. Tweedie, Mr. and Mrs. Broatch, Mr. Cyril Broatch, Mrs. and the Misses Guy, Mr. and Mrs. Roger, Mrs. Caffey and Miss O’Connor, Dr. and Mrs. Purdy, Dr. Meade, Dr. and Mrs. Stam^fl, Mrs. Snr.w, Mr. and Mrs. Delaney, Misses Stifle and Horner, M. and Mme. Riohe, M. Guérin, Miss Pem- berton, Mr. Tarrell, Mr. Ingram, Mr. Harwood, and others. The Floating Dock. The fbating dock, Admiral Dewey, was safely berth'd yesterday morning. It will be a feat of some magnitude to get the huge structure through the Canal, requiring the removal of bnoys and even widening in part!. Owing to the season of monsoons commenoiog, probably the dook will be plaoed in the Bitter Lake for some time. Souvenirs of Vesuvius, Souvenirs of the eruption of Vesuvius were brought to Port Said by the German steamer Rood, in the shape of ashes collected on the deck during her stay at Naples. Order at Port Said. The police of the town have gained great kudos for the management of the nnmerons fêtes and the maintenance of order. Port Said by night is as safe as Port Said bg day. There is really very little orime in the town, considering the temptations of a large port, where there is little restriction on the landing of nn- desirables, who have been cleared out of other Levantine ports. Approach of Summer. The town is beginning to take on a summer- like appearance, bathing-houses being rapidly moved up on the beach. Swimming and diving enthusiasts will have to find a new place, as owing to the widening of the harbour the old bathing location has been dismantled. Sport. Some of the sporting element have already oommenced cricket, the mnoh-played football aod hookey now being things of the past. Tennis, however, is as popular as ever, and will probably be oarried on right through the sommer. Freemasonry. The Aooient Order of Freemasons held a banquet last night, Mr. Tweedie, Worshipful Master, being in the chair, supported by Past- Master Swallow and the officers, visitor0, and friends.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN
div.p: (From our Correspondent). Suakin, April 18. Large consignments of new cotton are being despatched now to Suez. The Khédivial Mail steamer Mhvllah left here to-day with a fairly large oargo of cotton. Cotton at Tckar seems to be very good this year. Mrs. Gaiger, wife of Mr. Gaiger, English secretary to the Direotor of Railways, arrived here from Egypt by the 8.S. Mahallah on the 15th inst., and leaves here to day by express train for Atbara to pass the snmmer there with her husband.

div.head: THE CHURCH AT KHARTOUM.
div.p: HISHOP MATH'S APPEAL.

Bishop Blyth m.kes an appeal in the “Times” for more liberal support for the Khartoum Church Building Fond. He writes : I have just returned from a singularly interest- ing visitation tour in Fgypt, which extended To Khartoum iu the Sudan. The happy in- fluence ot a firm, just, and kindly Government, under a vigorous administrator, with a well- ohosen and united body cf colleagues, is every- where apparent in the peace and development of the country. Agriculture, oommeroe, educa- tion are all practically treated and made intelligible to the people ; and so is all that oonoern8 the general health of the country. I . should like the many hopeful subsoribers to the "Gordon College” to know that, to the Bishop's eye, their money could scarcely have been better laid out. Its educational aim seems to touch Dearly every Government branch, administrative, industrial, and medical, in their wider and scientific aims ; the native agents for the’e several purposes are beiDg trained there. It has a real mission for general good, and its aim is becoming manifest to the people. But my reason for writ;ng to yon is one that concerns my own department and I think it should interest the Chnrch laity very generally. The mantle of General Gordon’s happy blend of administrative wotk with a tone of personal religion seems to rest there still. There are few brighter and more heartily congrega- tional servioes than those which are held in the temporary chnrch room in the Palace ; the attendance there is nnatrained, general, and enconragiDg. And the natives seem greatly to respeot those who are not ashamed of the claims of their owa religion. Within a few' hundred yards of the plaoe where Gordon fell, and close to the remarkable broDzj statae ot the General on his oamel, ia the site of the new chnrch. The foondation-stone was laid last year by an Eaglish princess. They have about £3,500 towards £6,000 required for a ohurch. Whether in memory of the heroism of General Gordon, as the site suggests, or for the sake of those who are continuing his work with snoh unity of.-aim, and with such respect for their own religion (bat who cannot, of coorse, do for themselves what they have rightly done for the religion of the people— namely, ask a grant corresponding to that which they have given for a very beaatifal moeque), I would appeal for générons subscrip- tions. They shoold be sent to the “Secretary to the Chnrch Bailding Fond, the Palace, Khartoum.”

div.head: THE HEART OF RAMESES II.
div.p: The Comptes Rendus of the Paris Academy contains an account of the successful identifica- tion of the heart of Rameses II., the Sesostris of the Greeks, after preservation for more than 3,0; 0 years in soda and resinoid antiseptics. Some months ago the oonnoil of the National Museum of the Lonvre acquired possession of the f mr vases in bine enamel which oonthin the viscera and'heart of Rameses IL, and hear large medallions, representing the names and attributes of the King. The director of the Egyptian Museum desired absolute confirma- tion as to the ooutents of the vases, and en- trusted the examination of their contents to M. Lorfet, who with his colleagues, Professors Hugonnenq, Renan t, and Bigau, made a careful physiological examination. Three of tha vases contained bandages of linen tightly compacted and hardened by the carbonate of soda and aromatic îesinous substances of reddish color which bad been employed as antiseptics, and had probably contained the stomach, intestines, and liver of the great King. These viscera, how- ever, were only found to be represented by a quantity of granular matter mixed with a large proportion of powdered carbonate of soda, and so could not be identified. The fourth vase, which was fitted with a lid or cover adorned with the head of a jackal, proved to contain the heart. Tais organ wa» found trans- formed into a kind of oval plate, eight centi- mètres long and four centimètres wide. The substance of the heart wah horn-like, and the saw had to be used in obtaining sections of it for examination, and finally the razor, so as to reduce these sections to the attenaation neces- sary for microscopio examination. -Under the microscope these sections gave unmistakable evidence of the mnsoolar fibres pecnliai to the heart, especially characterized by being arrang- ed in bandies of sach fibres, orossiog each other. Since thisspeoial muscular arrangement is not found in any other part of the body, exoept the tongne, and as tha mammy of Rameses II., which is preserved at Cairo, oon- tains the topgne intact, the experts have no doubt whatever that the vase actually oontained the heart of Rameses II., flattened and trans- formed into a horn like substance by its long sojourn in the soda preservative. King RameseB II. died 1,258 years before the Christian era, and henpe some 3,164 years have elapsed since his heart was first embalmed.

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEGRAMS
div.p: ANGLO THIBETAN TREATY.
CHINESE PROTECTORATE RECOGNISED

Shanghai, April 23. The Aoglo-Thibetan treaty signed at Pekin g provides the recognition of a Chinese pro- tectorate over Thibet : Great Britain does not interfere internally nnless other Powers do ; China opens some Thibetan markets to Indian trade, and gives Great Britain the preference regarding the railway concessions : 2.400,000 taels, the expenses of the Yonnghnsband mission, are to be paid., (Reufe*)

div.head: EUROPE TO PERSIAN GULF
NEW GERMAN LINE OF STEAMER
div.p: Hamburg, April 23. The Hamburg-Amerika line of steamers will annonnoe shortly the inauguration of a new service from E irope to the Persian Golf. (Reuter)

div.head: The Natal Troubles
PREMIER AND IMPERIAL GOVERNMENT
div.p: Durban, April 23. Natal is recruiting a thousand mounted native scouts. The Premier of Natal, in addressing his constituents, rejeoted altogether the idea that the requisitioning of the assistance of Imperial troops entitled the Imperial Government to take the settlement out of the hands of the Natal Government. (Reuter)

div.head: SAN FRANCISCO FIRE
RENEWED OUTBREAK
div.p: San Francisco, April 23. Processes of restoration have already begun. Up to now about 500 bodies have been recover- ed but the extent of the mortality remains quite uncertain ; competent valuers estimate the total losses at, approximately, £60,000,000 of whioh £35,000,000 is oovered by insurance. A noteworthy faot is that the steelbuilt skyscrapers, including the famous Call building, are unhurt exteriorly, though gutted. A renewed outbreak of the fire has taken plaoe here: the docks are threatened. (R.)

div.head: FRENCH STRIKE DISTURBANCES
JEWELLERS NOW OUT
div.p: Paris, April 23. Numerous arrests are now being made in the Lens dietriot : the rioters seem overawed by the display of force. ( Reuter) Lens, April 23. Forty arrests have been made among the strikers. (Hamas) Paris, April 23. Six thousand working jewellers hava gor e out on strike. ( Havat

div.head: POSTAL CONGRESS.
ABYSSINIA'S STATUS.
div.p: Rome, April 23. Abyssinia has been granted a deliberative status at the Postal Congress in view of her impending entry into the Union, while China, which is not entering at present, has only a consultative status. (Reuter)

div.head: LANCASHIRE COTTON SPINNERS.
VOTE IN FAVOUR OF STRIKE.
div.p: London, April 23. Ninety-seven per cent, of 120,000 Lanca- shire spinners and oardroom workers involved in the dispute have voted in favour of a strike, if their demands are refused. It is believed tbat the employers will resist, unless the scheme for the automatic regulation of wages be simulta- neously arranged. (ReuUr)

div.head: COTTON FIRE ON SHIP.
div.p: Bremen, April 23. Three thousand bales of ootton have bien burned in the between decks of the S.£. Bisohoff. y (Haros)

div.head: EGYPTIAN RINCE ASHORE.
div.p: Malta, April 23. The S.3. Egyptian Prince is ashore here. The passengers have been landed. ' (Reuter)

div.head: KING EDWARD A GREEK ADMIRAL.
div.p: Athens, April 23. King George has appointed King Edward an Admiral of the Greek fleet. (Reutir)

div.head: SWEDISH PRINCE BORN.
div.p: Stockholm, April 23. Prinoess Adolph of Sweden has been deliver- ed ot a son. (Remter,

div.head: C.M.S. HOSPITAL AT OLD CAIRO
EARL OF MEATH'S VISIT
div.p: On Saturd vy week, the Earl and Countess of Meath paid a visit to the C.M.8. Hosprtal at Old Cairo, and inspected the new building * bat has recently been erected there. After tea in one of the houses, the gnests adjourned to the hospital dose by, and Lord Meath made a short speech from the steps of the new building. His lordship said that he had been asked to say a few woids with regard to the building they were about to inspect, and first alluded to the actual opening of the hospital, which took place in November last. It had been intended originally to invite friends to some oper ing oeremony at that date, bat certain obstacles made this impossible, and as the wards in the old hospital were very fall then,and those in the “Ethel Pain Memorial Hospital” were ready, it was decided to transfer at once all the women patients and the children to the new building, whioh has leen erected exclusively for them, aud ihas bring it into iSamediate use. Bet it had been felt th \t many would like to pea the completed building, and this opportunity had therefore been given. Lord Meath added that the total cost of the new wards was about £3,500.and up to Novem ber some £3.200 had been reoeivei towards that amoon\ But ow*ng to a recent gift of over £300 by a resident in Cairo, be had the plea- sure of saying, what he had rarely been able to Bay when opening various buildings in England, viz:—tint the new building was now entirely free of debt. Of tha furniture and appliances also, the greater part had been already provid- ed, and another recent gift of. £12.12. had enabled the doctors to order the beds required for the remaining unfarni had ward. Continuing with some general remarks, his lordship showed bow it was the Christian spirit tbat had praotioally originated and developed the idea of erecting hospitals for, and giving help to the sick, and said that in answer to anyone who might ask him why a missionary hospital should be maintained, now that hospi- tals are provided by the State, he woold reply that one reason alone w»s sufficient, viz to keep in reiqjsmbranoe all that is owed to the spirit of Christ, and to have at least one hospital openly associated with Christian‘y. The nations of the world whioh at the present time stand at the head of aH others, and are the most advance 1 in civilization,are those nations, whose inhabitants, speaking generally, profess the Christian faith. Let oar adhesion to that faith be more than a mere profession ; let it be seen by all men that it is a conviction of the heart as well. Christianity has proved itself to be wonderfnlly calculated to promote sooial progress and national development. We should then never allow ourselves by residence in non- Christian oonntries to fo'grft or to minimize the blessings whioh the Christian frith has brought to all peoples which have adopted it. This we oan do without off -nee to true and honest believers in other faiths bat a great responsibility rests on a Christian living in a non-Christian country with regard to his own faith. The more earnest the non-Christian is in his faith, the more he will respect the Christian who is' bold to assert with all love and courtesy his fi.m persuasion of theiparamoant claims of his own religion, and the surer will he despise the nominal Christian who is afraid to carry aloft in the eye3 of all men the standatd of Christ, or is indifferent or Worse, and thus brings by his actions discredit and reproach ou his religion. After some allusion to the early history of the Churoh Missionary Society and speo’el reference to the great part taken by the sooiety in the regenaration of India, Lord Meath re- ferred to the words of some of the most hohoùrei of the rqlers ofthat country when speaking of missionary enterprise. The great Lord Lawrenoa, formerly Governor-General of India, said, “Notwithstanding all that the Eaglish people have done to benefit India, the missionaries have dona more than all other agenoies combined.” No one oonld refuse to listen to the words of such an authority. They were not those of a “rabid religionist.” And they ware not delivered impromptu in a speech but written down as the expression of his true conviction. Sir yilliam Hooter also, the accomplished author of the “Imperial Gazetteer of India,” one of the greatest authorities on Indian sub- jects, wrote “English missionary enterprise is the habest modern expression of the world wide national li e of öur race. I believe any falling-off in Bugland's missionary efforts will be a sore sign of swiftly coming national decay.” And in the report of the Secretary of State and Council of India upon the moral and material progress of India in 1871 2 occurred these words:— ‘The Government of India cannot but ackn wledge the great obFgation ander wlrch it is laid by the benevolent exer- tions made by missionaries, whose blameless example and self-denying labours are iufasing new vigour inti the stereotyped lift» of the great populations placed ander English rale, and are preparing them to be in every way better men and better citizens of tba great Empire in which they dwell.” Lord and Lady Meath then went over both the hospitals, and aho’t’y before sunset made the;r departure en route t) the Mena Hanse Hotel.

div.head: DISCONTO-GESELLSCHAFT BERLIN.
div.p: The Disoonto-Gesellschaft of Berlin, whose balance-sheet is pabliçhed below, distributes ou the capital stock of £8,500,000, a dividend of 9 % against 8j % far the previous year, the atter rate having b? eu paid tor several years pas*. Including the reset va fand, the entire oapital would be M.227,600,00 ' =£11,380,000. Gross profits increased from £1,18*,050 in 1904 to 1,314 350, and net profi s from*£85 4.5 0 to £921,0 0. Commissions earned from onrrent aocoonts amount to £276,409 (19)4: £*?52,900,V Debits in current aooonnts aggregated on December 31st, 1905, £15,959,942 (1304: £13,3 >6,6 0 ). oredits £10,770,053 ( 1904 : £9,296,100); and deposits £5,502,470(1904: £5,001,900). The Dnoonto-Gesellsohaft has taken a very active part in the issuing business daring the past year. Like all the other large German financial institutions it has enlarged its clien- tèle by affiliating existing firms and by found- ing new bank*. The Disoonto-Gesellaobaft, which owns the entire oipital stock of M. 60,000,000=£2,500.0C0 of the Norddeutsche Bank iu Hambarg, retains also its interest in a number of oiher banks throagh its ownership of shares which have been acquired in former years. To these belong the “All- gemeine Deutsche Cred’t-Austalt” in Leipeig, the “Banque Générale Roumaine” in Buoharest, the “Deutsch-Asiatische Bank,” the “Bank für Chile und Deutschland,” and the “Brasiliani- ohe Bank für Deutdohland.” Tha permanent participations io other banks, in addition to the oapital of the Norddeutsche Bank in Ham- burg, amount to £1.559,500(1904: £887,650). All these institutions thaw a very satisfactory progress and have given gratifying results. The same may be said of the great industrial andrailwyenterpriaesinforeignooiintries,whioh are patronised by the Disconto-Geaellsobafc or in which it is interested, vis : the “Sohantnng Eiseubabu-GaseUfechalt,” the “Schantung Berg- bau Gesellschaft,” the “Otavi Mineu-undFisen- bahn Gesellschaft,” in German SonthMTest Africa, the ‘ Compagn e Parisienne de Fair com- primé,” in which the Disoonto-Gesellschaft has an interest throagh the “Internationale E/ek- trici*ä s Gesellschaft,” and the “Petioleom Undertakings” in Roumania.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: MINIEG SECOND SKYE MEETING

The eloring meeting of tht season took place on Friday, 20th iost., in splendid weather. H.K the Mondir and all the well-known resi- dents were present, together with many visitors from the neighbouring provinces. Every avail- able inch in the three eutioeares was occupied, whilst the free portion of tbe ground was thronged with infereitedspeoUtorsto the num- ber of two thon'and at least. Entries were nameroos, so mooh so that the first race on the oard, the Fellaheen Stakes, had to be duplicated, and daring tbe afternoon sevunty-five herse» took part in the five events. The racing was good and the addi- tion of a few gymkhana events added a touch of f i rolity to an already interesting pro- gramme. Tbe events of the day.rz., the Minieh Plate and the Ladies' Bracelet, were won respective ly by Kotb Effendi Abdalla's Maghoul and Kamel Effendi Maher’s Matacawi, the latter horse being in a d:ffarent class to anythiog else competing in the race. Mr. Boxwtll, riding Omar Bey Saltan’s Bahnassa, was second in the Braoelet. The final event of th» day was a tog-of-war between soldiers and ghaffirs, tbe latter winning decisively amidst intense popu- lar exoitement. An excellent tea was provided in tbe com- mittee’s enclosure by Omar Bey 8altan, and the local baud enlivened ptoeeedings. with appropriate strains of music. The polioe arrange- ments were excellent, and giwt praise is due to Omar Bey Saltan for his generosity in pro- viding aid preparing-such an excellent race- course. Details follow Fellaheen Stakes (one mile) (a )—1st, Yanis Eff. Tarrai’s Rabab ; 2nd, Abd el-Baki Eff. Abu Ganima’s Aysub ; 3rd, Issa Ibrahim’s Asfurah 11. (6>) 1st, Amin Eff. div.head: THE SHRINE OF SAINT MENAS
div.p: A MODERN PILGRIMAGE
BY H. BINDERNAGEL

When Admiral Sir Massie Blomfield a year âgo wrote his most interesting study in the bulletin of the Alexandria Arohæologioal Society on the probable site of the sanotnary of Saint Monas, he could oertainly not snppose that at; that very time an expedition was crossing the whole rf the Waiad Ali Desert and Mariont with the definite object of di?co vering the historical oity of St. Mena«. After 4 a winding march of 30 days this expedition of the Frankfort arcbanlogist, the Rev. Carl Maria Kaufmann, and his oo-operator, Mr. Fa’ls, reaohed on the 8th Jane last an ex- tensive area of rains, the Arabic denomination of which—Kann Abûtn or Boomna—in itre'f roa8ed their cheerful hopes, as it was not difficult to recognizé the derivation from Karm Abft Mina. The discovery of many of those well known eulogies of St. Mena», as well as of one of the ovens serving for their manu* factors, together with the recognition of a large A nais in the stone chaos of the ruins, left no doubt in the miuds of the mem- bers of the expedit'on that the long-looked- for national sanotuary of the old-Christian Egyptians bad really been discovered. For about four months past the Rev. Kauf- mann and Mr. Falls have been aotively engag- ed in excavating under moat difficult condi- tions and it is dae to their kindness that I am able to set before the Alexandria Arolæo- logical Society the f jllowiog particulars of the résulta obtained up to date. The vast terri- tory of mine, the largest in Mariout, is situat- ed about a two hours' ride south east of Behig station on the Khedive's railway,in a road less and waterless desert. A chain of low lying hills, already visible from afar, unrolls itself on approach into a number of koms and fields of mins, the oentre of which is formed by the high shrine of St. Menas. Amidst lofty heaps of rains one descends into the marble resplen- dent basilica of Arcading. One is in the vast oruoiform ohuroh which at the end of the fourth oentury, almost exactly a hundred years after the death of the martyr, was erect- ed as an enlargement of the original basilica by the art-loving ruler of E vstern Rome. It may be mentioned here that there is not in Egypt a single site of ruins where the type of an old-Christian basilica is preser- ved so pure and genuine. In front of the Apsis, of a breadth of about 11 metres, and before the marble facing, whiob still clearly reveals traces of incendiarism, rises the altar, to which five steps, plaoed semi-oiron- larly, lead ap. It is surrounded by the square, "acho)m aantorom," to the rich marble balus- trade of which many fine fragments testify. Within this barrier there is a pit, flanked larger for water. The above-mentioned graffito solves the question in favour of holy water, which the pilgrims took away with them as a token of remembrance or perhaps for usage in disease). What connexion there may he between this find and a huge oistern with several deep descending-shafts, discovered under the older St. Menas Church, further researches will reveal. Not f*r from one of there shafts the retaining walls are yet to be seen, whioh the Patriarch Joseph of Alexandria had ordered to he erected, after the Khalifa Bl-Mutiwakil had robbed Mar Mina of its most preoions columns in order to adorn with them the mosques and palacee of Cairo. An octogonal construction, thebqitisfe ium, adj dns the two basilioas jast described. Here somo fine oapi tals with dove ornament were found. The fallen cupola shows in its orown the monogram of Christ. Hi ra also the excavations may yet lead to interesting finds. It would tike up too muoh spaoe for me to enter upon further details far the-exoavationp. Besides a number of tomb corridors and cham- bers, bordering the basilic* to the South, special mention, however, ought to be made of a seiies of cistern) and baths unearthed in another part of the oity and wh;oh perhaps are identical with the old-Christian Xenodocheion. Two sepulohral churohes, wlrch are situated far away at opposite points of the oity, may also be mentioned. One of them, whioh I visited, is surrounded by a cemetery of the fourth oanfcury. Besides the Apsis it possesses in old-Christ:an f*shion Prjthesis and Dia- konikoD, as well as a nice bapjtisterinm en- vironed by columns. Close to the modest woodhouse constructed and inhabited by the two German explorers and surrounded by their Bedouins’ tsnts, a quantity of ovens for the manufaotaie of Menas fltsks and ampul’æ were found. I think it w mid be a worthy objeot for the Archæ logical Society or for enlightened and well-to do members of the different communi- ties of our oity to support the researches of the resting-place of the Alexandrian martyr, the means at the disposal of the meritorious explorers being nearly exhausted. A still deeper Os- auarium exists at the back of the Apsis, below whioh seve-al massively-vaulted fane rary chambers with descending shafts lead beluw the altar. The cross-nave, 50 metres large and supported by 24 oolumns, ends in two small Apsides. Everywhere traoes of most ooBtly decorations are to be seen ; broken oolumns and splendid capitals of briliant tmatble, tumble-down pieces of masonry and foundation blooks are lying about Here and there appear patches of inlaid marble fl iorir g. Chiselled into one of the foundation pieces we find a neat Greek inscription, containing a eulogy compose! on Easter-Day by a oer- tain Theodotos, possibly the arohiteot of the basilic*. On the southern lide-naye three doors open upon the atrium of the basilioa. A semioircu’ar tower-shape! wall at the |®8t end of the long nave represents the principal Apaia of the smaller and oldest St. Menas basilica, the enlargement of which is the Inge Arcadius basilioa above described. Here the work is still proceeding and most eagerly watched. A dome-covered oobicu- lom has already been excavated and many " fragments give evidence of its splendid mosaic faoing. div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER.”

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature’s Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: Circulaire H. De Vries et Boutigny
div.p: NOTES ET CRITIQUES

L9 Caire, le 23 avril. A Londres, avant hier, le Consolidé anglais a o’ôturé à 90, soit en nouvelle baisse de 1/8. L’Uuifiée, la National Bank, l’Agricole et la Duïra sont restées invariées à leors oours pré- cédents La Delta Light a encore perdu 1/8 à 12 5/8 A Paris, l’action Crédit Foncier Egyptien a réagi de 2 f à 785 et la Banque d’Athènes de 1 frano à 152. * * * Comme il fallait s’y attendre apièj les oours d’Europe de samedi, nous avons eu, oe matiD, un marché indécis, aveo peu de transsctions et des prix soit invariés, soit légèrement pins frib’es sur la plupart de) valeurs, à fort peu d’exceptions prè*. La National Bank est revenue à 26 13/16, l’Agri'Jo’e à 10 1/8, le Comptoir Financier à 7 18/16. L’action Crédit Fonoier est restée immobile à 786 ; par contre» la part de fondateur a enoore haussé de 80 francs à 1090. L’Héliopolis a été traitée e ître 335 et 330 ; la part de fondateur à 13 1/4. La part de fon- dateur Nile Land a monté à £75. La part de fondateur Wardan Estate a été recherchée à t L’action Entreprises Immobilières et Tra- vaux s’est tenue à 4 13/32 ; la part de fonda- teur à 82. L'aotion Nile Expreis a é‘é éjhan- gée aux abords du pair ; la part de fondateur à 67. L’Immobilière a réaotionné à 875 ; la part de fondateur à 625. Li mouvement de hausse que nous avions pressenti sur les Improvements s’est des iné rapidement : on a clôturé à 5 1/16, après avoir atteint 5 1/8. C’est là un oemmenoement, car le titre vaut beaucoup plus. Parmi les der- nières opérations réalisées par oette Socié é, seule oa eu participation, on pent oiter l’aohat des terrains Hekekian, me Soliman Pacha, d’un vaste terrain de grand avenir sis en faoe de la Gare, des terrains Gianaolis à Kasr-el-Nil, du pala;s de la prinoesse Zainab, me Mansour- Pachs, eto. Les offres déjà reçues pour quel- ques-unes ds ces affaires assurent an fort bean profit. En outre, la Sooiété a été chargée de l’administration de plusieurs grandes proprié- tés, ce qui oonstitae une soorœ importante de bénéfices. Il y a en nne fort bonne demande en Ciments, qui ont monté de 70 à 76. Dans le groupe des Hôtels les Nungovioh sont restés à 18; les Upper Egypt sont revenus à 4 11/16—3/4. Parmi les petites valeurs, les Delta Land ont été échangés entre 4 13/16 et 27/32; les Hooker outre 1 1/8 et 3/16. Les Estates ont été traités, ex-oonpon de 2 sh., entre 1 7/8 et 15/16 Les Sait and Soda ont été ramenés à 23 sh. 9. Les Poit-8aïd Sait ont été demandés à 15 sh. 3. Lea New Egyp- tian ont fléchi à 30 sh. 9 pour remonter à 31.9. • • Nous avons reçu plusieurs lettres par les- quelles on nous demande des renseignements sur le "Crédit Fonoier Hollandais" dont one émission de titres est annoncée pompeusement depuis qaelques jours à la 4ème page des journaux. Tout d'abord, nous devons déclarer que nous sommes absolument étrangers à oette affaire, contrairement à oe que l'on semble avoir fait accroire à quelques-uns de nos cor- respondants. Ensuite, à en juger dn moins par les annon- ces susmentionnées, il ne s’agit guère d’ane entreprise fonoière, mai) tout bonnement d'une loterie dans le genre de celles dont la vente des billets en Egypte est, croyons nous, interdite par le règlement en vigueur depuis l’année der- nière. * * * * Il résulte dn rapport qui sera présenté à l’assemblée de la Brasserie des Pyramides, con- voquée pour le 2 Mai à Bruxelles, que l’exer- oioe 1905 accnse sur le précédent on surplus net de recettes de LE. 4,195. En déduisant les frais d’administration, charge d’intérêts, eto., et en ajoutant la somme reportée de 1904, on arrive à nn total de Frs. 108,744, représentant le bénéfice net à fin 1905. Après prélèvement de la réserve statutaire, il reste un solde de Frs. 103,305 qui permet la distribution d’an dividende de Frs. 5 par ao- tion de capital, laissant Frs. 8,242 à reporter à nouveau. Le conseil propose que oe premier dividende soit payé le 15 Mai prochain. Le rapport expose finalement qne la vente du terrain de Ghixeh met la Société à même de rembourser tonte sa ditte (850,000 Frs. d’obligations 5 %) et de constituer un fonds de roulement de Frs. 200,000. « * « Ou noua informe d’Alexandrie qu’à l’as semblée extraordinaire de la Port-Said Salt \ssooiation, qui a en lieu avant-hier dans l’après midi, le projet de fusion avec la Sait and Soda a été rejeté à nne grande majorité des voix. A la suite de ce vote, deux membres du conreil d’administration se sont retiré). L’assemblée ordinaire, qui s’est tenue aussi- tôt aprè°, a adopté les comptes de l'exeroiœ 1905 et autorisé la distribution d’un dividende de f % net. Elle a co* firmé le cho:x de M. Petoovioh comme administrateur-dé égoé et a élu MM. Vernnnd et Geo Sait comme non vea~x administrateur*.

En réaction également les Upper Egypt Hotels à 4 1/2 et les îjndateurs Epates à 113,4. Peu d’affaires, d'ailleurs, exoepté en A jri cole, Delta Light, Sait and Soda, et Trust. La Delta Landet la Hooker sont prenne passées de mode, ainsi que l’ln vest ment, le Trust et la Cassa di Sconto. Selon toute probabilité oette tendance ne fera que s’accentuer d’ici à la fin du mois.

div.head: LA CONCESSION DE L’EZBEKIEH
div.p: Le oahier des oharges pour l’adj adioation de l’exploitation artistique du théâtre du jardin de l’Ezbékieh pour l’année 1907, contient les danses prinoipales suivantes : Le contrat pourra être renouvelé au gré des parties; le cautionnement est fixé à L.K 500;le concessionnaire ne pourra pas convertir le théâtre en café-concert et devra y donner ex cluaivement des speotacles de prose, opéras et opérettes ; en cas de sons-Iooation, il ne pourra percevoir plus du 40 *% s’il s’agit de speotacle de prose et plus de 20 % pour les autres spec taoles ; le concessionnaire est obligé à payer les frais d’éclairage et d’eau, ainsi que ceox d’em bellis8ement et réparations et ne pourra donner que 120 représentations par an et, en hiver, il ne pourra donner de spec taoles d’opéra sans le consentement du gouvernement L’djudioatiou aura lieu au mois de juin,

div.head: GRECE ET EGYPTE
div.p: Voici en substanœ les prinoipales olaoses du nouvel arrangement commercial intervenu entre la Grèoe et l’Egypte : Assurance de l’introduotion en Egypte, pen- dant tonte la durée de l’arrangement des tabacs hellènes ; assurance de l’exterritorialité hellène en cas de perquisition de la part deB autorités policières ou administratives. De son côté le gouvernement hellène a ao- oordé à l’Egypte les facilités voulues pour la restriction des tripots fonctionnant sous diffé- rentes formes et déposera à la Chambre hellène deux projets de loi, l’on interdisant l’exporta- tion du harchiohe de la Grèoe en Egypte ; l’autre portant que les contrebandiers de hasohiohe seront, après dénonciation des auto- rités égyptiennes,déférés an tribunal consulaire hellène et punis des pénalités prévues par la loi hellène pour les contrebandiers.

The Subscription List will open on Wednesday, 25th April, 1906, and olose on or before Thurs- day 26th April, at noon, at the Offioes of the Anglo-Egyptlan Bank, Ltd., at Alexandria and Cairo, This Prospectus has been filed with the Registrar of Joint Stock Companies. Egypt and Levant Steamship COMPANY, LIMITED. (To bo Incorporated under the Companies' Acts, 1862 to 1000.) Capital , . . £200,000 Divided into 199,000 Ordinary 8hares of £l each, and 20,000 Deferred Shares of Is. each. The holders of the Ordinary Shares are entitled (1) to a fixed onmnlative dividend at the rate of 5% per annum on the capital for the time being paid op or credited as paid op thereon respectively, and to 60% of the sorplos profits which in each year it shall from time to time be determined to distribute remaining after paying or providing for the payment of the said fixed onmnlative dividend ; (9) to priority as to retorn of capital and payment off of arrears of dividend whether deolared or not op to the commencement of the winding op. The Deferred Shares confer on the holders thereof rateably and in proportion to the nom- 4 ber of Deferred Shares held by them respec- tively the right to 4% of the sorplos profits which in respect of each year it shall from time to time be determined to distribote remaining after paying or providing for the payment of the B&id fixed comolativa dividend on the Ordinary Shares. Of the above 199,000 Ordinary Shares, 60,000 are payable as part of the Parohase- Money as mentioned herein, and 61,000 will be reserved tor private sobscription. Subscriptions are invited from the public at par for 75,000 Ordinary Share?. Payable 10% on Application, 16% on Allot- ment, 25% on the 15th Jane, 1906. and the balance, viz., 50%, on the 15th Joly, 1906. Share Warrants to Bearer will be delivered free of stamp daty to Original Sabsoribers upon payment of their Shares in fall, bat no payment in anticipation will carry with it any right to dividend on the amoont so paid in advanoe. Direotorst IN EGYPT. Hesry Edward Barker, Esq., of Messrs. Barker & Co., Alexandria. Shipping Agent». Percy William Carver, Esq., Alexandria. Merchant. William Bekwell Rees, Esq., Alexandria. Merchant. IN LONDON. Hesry Lam run, Esq., of Messrs. Alfred Laming A Co., 8, Lcadcnhall Street, E.C. Ship Owners and Agents. IN SMYRNA. Thos. Bowes Rees, Esq., Govoming Director T. Bowen Rees & Co., Limited. Hesry R. De Josoii, Esq., Manager T. Bowen Rees & Co., Ltd. (Ex-Officio) Bankers t National Provincial Bank or Enoland, Ltd.* Asolo-Egyptian Bank, Ltd., Alexandria and Cairo. Imperial Ottoman Bank, Smyrna. Solicitors t Mwuira Pritchard A Sons, 9, Graoechurch.Street, London, E.C. Legal Advisor In Egypt. A. 8. Preston, Esq., Advocate, Alexandria. Auditors t Measrs. Russell, Kerr & Wyatt, Alexandria. Brokers ; Comptoir Financier et Commercial d’Eoypte, Alexandria. Secretary & London Offices t John William Stranghan, 8, Leadonhall Street, London, E.C. Managers i T. Bowen Rees & Co., Ltd., Smyrna. Agents In Alexandria i Mossrs. Barker & Co. PROSPECTUS. This Company has been formed for the por- p088 specified in the Memorandom of Associa- tion and in partionlar (1) to take over and acquire the good will and business of the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., together with the existing fleet cf steamers of the Com- pany, consisting of four steamers of large car- rying capacity. (2) To acquire and/or baild new steamers or other vessels. (3) To ( ontinne and develop the trade which has been carried on for the last 14 years by the Talbot Steam- ship Company between Smyrna and other Levant ports, Egypt and the United Kingdom. (4) Generally to carry on the business of ship- owners in all its branches in the same or other parts of the world. It is considered by the Directors of this company that the present is a favourable foment for extending the shipping business already developed by the Talbot Steamship Company, more particularly as there is every probability of there being favourable oppor- tunity of acqoiring new tonnage at low cost. The Talbot Steamship Company has always enjoyed a high reputation in the Levant and has financially stood on a sound basais ; like other shipping conoerns, its profits have been affected at times by depression in freights, but bad and good years taken together the average net earnings over the whole period of its existence have been very satisfactory, in spite of heavy, mamgement charges, which, under the new arrangement, will be considerably reduced. The volume of trade has so increased that additions to the fleet are absolutely necessary. TL shares of the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., are held in very few hands, and instead of farther increasing its capital it has beei^ determined to make over its present bating and steamers to this company. It is proposed to build, or, if aiavonrable opportunity offers, boy at once four new steamers, whicji, fitted with all the latest appliances, wonlj' be run on the most econo- mical lines as tçî coal consomption, cost of working, etc. It is confidently expected that with an increased fleet and facilities the new Company will at once take quite a leading position In the Lovant as shipowners and command a steadily increasing clientèle amongst shippers. The four steamers and their tbcklr, apparel, etc., to be taken over from the Talbot Steam ship Company, Ltd., bavj been valued by the well-known steamship valoers Messrs. Kellook & Co., of London, as follows :— S. 8. Antonio, £28.500 ; 8. S Wingrove, £19,000 ; 8.8. Cabral, £16,000 ;S.S. Hnbbnck, £12,000 ; or a total of £75,500.

The vaine of the goodwill of the business of the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., has been fixed at £’0,0C0 by that Company. The Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., whose registered offices is at 4, St. Mary Axp, London, E. C., has »greed to sell to Mr. J. D Langdon, as a Trustee on behalf of the new Company, the whole of ite fleet and the good- will of its business at these prices, v‘z. £75.500 for the steamers and £10,COO for the goodwill, or a total of £85.500. This price will be paid : £60,030 in folly paid Ordinary Shares of the Company and the balance in cash. The business of the Talbot Steamship Com- pany, Ltd., will be taken over as a going oon oern from the 1st May, 1906, and the Company will take all profits after that date. The following contracts have been entered into ■a Agreement dated the 12th April, 190^6. Between the Talbot Steamship Company, Limi- ted. of on9 part and J D. Langdon as trustee on behalf of the new Company of the other part providing for the sale of the above m m- tioned steamers and goodwill of the business at the above prices. b Agreement dated the 12th April, 1906. Between the new Company of the one part and T. Bowen Rees and Company, Limited, of the other part whereby T. Bowen Rees and Com- pany, Limited, are appointed the Managers of this Company at the following remuneration : (1) an allowance ont of the annnal profits of £230 per annum towards o$cea and olerks’ salaries npon each steamer owned or managed by the Company ; (2) in every year in whioh the profits of the Company shall amount to 10 percent, or less npon the share capital for the time being paid op, an additional remuneration equal to 10 per cer t, on sneb net profits ; (3) in every year in which suoh profits shall exceed snch 10 per cent. a remuneration equal to 15 percent on snch net profit?, bat in this event the Managers receive no remnneration under (2) . The term "profits” means the earnings of the steamers dr other income of the Company after charging steamers’ workirg expenses, debenture interest, and interest on loans. The Managers are also entitled to charge the nsnal brokerage or commission, and agency fees when they act as loading or consignment brokers the onstomary brokerage on premiums of insurance, and the nsnal commission of 1 per cent, for collecting and adjasting insurance c’aimp. (c) A Contract dated the 12th day of April, 1906, and made between James Davee Lang don, of Smyrna, Merchant, of the one part, and T. Bowen Rees, as a Trustee for and on behalf of this Company of the other part, whereby in consideration of an option given to Mr. J. D. Langdon to apply for and to have allotted to him all the Deferred Shares in the Company for whioh he will pay in cash, the said J. D. Langdon agrees to subscribe or to proonre subscriptions for the whole of the present issue. Sob underwriting oontraots have been enter- ed into by the said James Davee Langdon with various persons. There are, in addition, contraota of an ordi- nary trade character which the Company will take over from the Talbot Steamship Company, Limited, as hereinbefore mentioned. Except the shares issued to the Talbot8team- ship Company, Ltd., no shares of this issne will be issued as fnlly or partly paid up other wise than in oash, Except as aforesaid no promotion money will be paid. The preliminary expenses of and incidental to the formation of the Company, down to and including allotment, including registration fees and stamp duty, legal expenses, the cost of advertising and issuing this prospectas, bat excluding stamp doty on share warrants and registration fees on transfer of the steamers, will be paid by the Company, and are estimat- ed at £3,000. The number of Shares fixed by the Articles of Association as the qualification of a Direotor is 500 Ordinary Shares. The following Directors are interested in the promotion of the Company and to the following extents — Messrs. W. B. Rees, T. B. Rees and H. R. de Jongh are Shareholders in the Talbot Steam ship Company Ltd. to the extent respectively of 100 shares, 152 shares and 40 shares of £100 each. Mr. T. B. Rees owns almost the entirety of the share capital in T. Bowen Rees & Co., Ltd., the managers of the new company. Mr. H. Rr. de Jongh, as Manager of T. Bowen Rees and Company, Limited, is entitled to one-third of the net profits of that company. Mr. H. E. Barker and Mr. T. Bowen Rees are interested as members of their respective, company and firm as agents of the new Comp- any in Smyrna and Alexandria and will be entitle^ to charge the- nsnal brokerage or com- mission fees as loading or consignment brokers or agents. Mr. Henry Laatfjhg, as sole partner in the firm of Alfred LamiDg and Company, who. it is proposed, will act as agents in London of the Company, will be entitled to the remuneration, not yet fixed, to be received by such agents from the Ci mpany. 4 Any Director who may snb-nn der write any shares of this issue will receive as the nominee of Mr. J. D. Langdon an allotment of deferred shares for whioh he will pay. The provisions of the Arfioles of Association with regard to the remuneration of the Di- rectors are as follows : — “As remuneration for their services each of the Directors (offier than the ex officio Di- rectors, who being the Managers shall re* eive no remuneration for acting es Directors) shill be paid ont of the funds of the Com- pany in each year a som ealcnlated at the rate of £100 for each steamer owred by the Company ; this remuneration will be eqaally divided between the Direotors, unless they shall otherwise determine. The Company in

General Meeting eh ill have power from time to time to vary or alter sooh remuneration if (he Direotors in snch manner as it shall think fit. If any Direotor, not being an ex officio Director, shall be called upon to perform extra services or to make any speoial exertions for the purposes of the Company, the Company shall remunerate the Direotor so doing, either by a fixed snm or by a per- centage of profits, or otherwise as may be determined by the Direotors, and snoh re- muneration may be either in addition to or in substitution cf his remnneration, as pro vided in the last preceding article.” Application for shares should be made on the aooompanying form and forwarded with cheque for the amoont payable on application to the Company’s Bankers, the Anglo-Egyptian Bank, Ltd., at Alexandria and Cairo. If no allotment is made the application money will be returned in foil and where the number of shares allotted is less than the number applied for the snrplos will be oredited in redootion of the amount payable gn allotment and aDy excess will be retarned to the applieant, Failure to pay any instalment of shares, when dne.will render previous payments diable to be forfeited. The minimum sobscription npon whioh the Direotors may proceed to allotment has been fixed by the Articles of Association at 10 per cent, of the shares offered. The whole of the present issue of shares has, however, as stated above, been underwritten. A copy of the Memorandum of Association whioh forms part of this prospectus is endorsed hereon. A brokerage of 3d. per share will be paid to Bankers and Brokers on all shares applied for and allotted to the pnblio on forms of applica- tion which bear their stamps. The valuation of Messrs. Kellock & Co,, and the above-mentioned contracts or copies of these documents, together with a print of the Company’s Memorandom and Artioles ot Asso- ciation may be inspected at the offices of the Comptoir Finanoier et Commercial d’Egypte and cf the Legal Adviser to the Company at Alexandria. Copies of this prospeotns and application forms can be obtained at the same effioes and at the offices of the Bankers of the Company at Cairo and Alexandria, Dated Alexandria, 21st April, 1906.

div.head: La Societe Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh
div.p: AVIS

La Société Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh met anx enchères publiques la vente de denx lots de terrains de construction sis à Minieh à côté de l’ancien palais vendu à M. Philippe Back. Le lot N°. 1,—est d’nne superficie de 3300 mètres oarré^ environ et le lot N°. 2,— est de 9600 mètres oarrés environ —La mise à prix a été reipeotivement fixée à P. T. 80 et P. T. 40 le mètre carré. Des offres seront reçues pour l’achat de l’on on des deux lots jnsqn’aa samedi 28 oourant à 11 heures da matin. Elles devront être adressées à S. E. le Directeur Général de la Sooiété Egyptienne de la Daira Sanieh sous enveloppe cachetée et portant cette 'mention "Offre pour l’achat dn lot No.— de terrains de Minieh”. Ces offres doivent être accompagnées d’an cautionnement de L. E, 250 poor le No. 1, de L. R 4( 0 pour le lot No. 2 et de L. R 650 pour les deux lots ensemble. Ces cautionnements devront être effectués soit par paiements en espèces à la Caisse de la Sooiété, dans ses bnreanx Rae Abdin, soit par mandat postal, soit par ohèque snr one banque dn Caire, dûment accepté par cette Banque, soit par envoi dn montant en billets de la Banque Nationale. La Société se réserve le droit de refuser on d’aoccapter n'importe quelle offre sans antre obligation pour elle que la restitntion des cautionnements. Cette vente est soumise anx danses et con- ditions de cette Sooiété pour tontes ses ventes. L’offre doit mentionner le mode d’après lequel le prix sera payé. Si l’offre oomporte le paie- ment intégral avant 1a prise de possession, oeloi dont l’offre serait aooeptée doit s’engager à parfaire le prix aussitôt que la Sooiété l’aura avisé de l’aooeptation de son offre. Si l’uffre oomporte le paiement à termes, celai dont l’offre aura été acceptée devra s’engager à par- faire le trente poor cent da prix aussitôt que la Sooiété l’aura avisé de l’aooeptation de son offre.Le solde du prix sera payé indifféremment soit en qainze annaités, avec an intérêt de 5 % l’an, soit en 20 annuités, aveo un intérêt de 5 1/2 % l’an. Dans l’un on l’antre oas la première annuité est d’éohéance le 1er Octobre 1906. Aussitôt qu’ane offre est acœptée.racqaérenr doit payer soit le solde da prix soit le complé- ment dn 30 % et se rendre à l’invitation de la Sooiété pour la Signatare de l’aote de vente, fante de qnoi la Société se réserve le droit de ré- sillier sa promesse de vente et de confisquer le cautionnement.

Municipalité d’Alexandrie. AVIS CONCERNANT LES RATS. Cette époque de l’année oeïnoidant aveo la réapparition de la peste, les autorités sanitaires croient devoir rappeler le rôle prépondérant qne jouent les rats dans la propagation de oette épidémie. Elles engagent les habitants de la Ville et ( principalement les personnes qui sont parti- * oulièrement exposées au oon tact des rats (telles1 qne b&kals, marchands d’huile, de farine, de savon, propriétaires d’éonries, etc ) à faire nsage des ratières et des boalettes empoisonnées qne la Mnnioipalité met gratuitement à leur dis- position. . Les autorités sanitaires accordent une prime de P.T. 20 pour tont rat qui aura été reconnu atteint, ou seulement suspect de peste. Tontes les fois qu’on voudra faire parvenir dans oe but, des rats an laboratoire, on s’abstiendra de les y apporter toi-même, mais on les mettra, en les prenant si possible aveo des pincettes, dans un seau, et l’on préviendra la Municipalité on l’Hôpital dn Gouvernement. L'A dministrateur (Signé) W. P. Chatawày. Alexandrie, le 21 Avril 1906.

Administration des Chemins de Fer de l’Etat Egyptien. .A. V I S L’Administration des Chemins de fer de l’Etat a l’honnenr de porter à la oonnaissar es dn Pablio qa’à partir dn 15 Mai 1906 les arti- oles soi vante : fèves, blés, maïs, orges, lentilles, helbés, lapins et pois chihes, qui seront trans- portés par oharge complète on inoomplète de tontes les gares de la Haute-Egypte situées an Snd d’Abou-el Noamrous (inclusivement) à destination des gares de la Basse-Egypte (y compris le Caire, Ghizffi, BonlaorDaorour et Embabeh), seront taxé3 au taux^ la 6me classe dn Tarif Général des Marchandises, aveo nne rédaction de 25 %. Cette rédaction s’étendra également snr les "Tibns” qni seront expédiés des gares de la Haute-Egypte an Sud d’Abou el-Nomrous (in- clusivement) à destination des gares de la Basse-Egypte (y compris les sas-mentionnées) par chargement complet (avec nn minimum de 6,000 kilog8.) et taas responsabilité pour l’Administration. Ces dispositions seront mises en vignenr jusqu’au 31 Août 1906 et seront appliquées seulement sur le prix de transport. Les frais accessoires seront perças an oomplet. Le Caife, le 18 Avril 1906.

div.head: SEMOULERIE PERFECTIONNEE
div.p: "LE LYS” J’ai l’honnenr d’informer le pablio et pins spécialement ma respectable olien’èle qup, tout en gardant mon moulin à farines de Ta sons (Turquie d’Asie), fondé en 1890, je viens d'ins- taller à Alexandrie nne semonlerie de tont dernier modèle fonctionnant d’après les sys- tèmes perfectionnés les pins récents de France et de Snisse. Grâce à ma longue expérience dans ce genre d’industrie, ainsi qa’aux moyens exceptionnels dont je dispose poor m’appro- visionner en blés de tont premier ohoix an Syrie, dans le Levant et en Rassie, j’espère don voir donner pleine et entière satisfaction sons tons les rappoits. Dans l’espoir que voas voudrez bien me con- server votre pratique et faire l’essai dn produit de ma nouvelle usine, Agréez, etc. Gabriel Marino. Mon bureau se trouve à côté de la Poste de Ras-el-Tin.—Téléphone N° 17-68—et la fabri- que dans le même quartier, Rue Gouda. P.S.— On pent se procurer dans le même établissement dn son, des criblnres et de la farine. 27600-15A-11
